title: How many deaths attributed to COVID-19 in the U.S. will be reported for the week ending 27 March 2021?
preds: The last two days had higher death counts (7-day moving sum), which deviate from the overall trend. I still expect a quite steady decline of deaths, but the question is, how soon does the trend return. I think that 26.03.2021 determines the outcome of this question. If the 7-day moving sum is below 6500 on the 26th, I expect that we'll end up below 6000 on the 27th. Contrary, if it is over 6500, I would be more inclined to believe that we'll end up above 6000. At this point, I feel it is pretty much 50 % for the outcome of the 26th.
Last seven days show about 6800.  It will be in the 6K to 8K bin.
7-day rolling average ~ 1000. However the rolling average has been on a downward trend, hence a non-trivial chance of ending under 6000.
With more people getting the vaccine, there should be fewer people dying from covid
Numbers went worse today but I still expect the declining trend to go on.

Threshold for 4K is 571 per day.  Current rate just under 1k.  
1916 for 21 to 23, 3 days.  Leaves 2084 for 4k or 500 per day and 4084 for 6k or 1021 per day.
21 to 23 average was 683, but these included the lower weekend days.  Plus when numbers are vire used they usually go up a bit, which means the total for these three days could creep up a little higher.  
Expect the remaining 4 days to be at or about 1k,  will be close to 6k but expect to pass this number
Based on the steady decline rate of deaths past 27 days.
This week's reported U.S. deaths (through 3/23/21) have been relatively low so far; around 2,000 total. https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html
Looking mid week at the current rate and decline trajectory.  I initially way overestimated.

7-day-moving average as of 23 March: 975 (*7=6825); trend: flattening 21: 456
22: 638
23: 936
24: ? (but usual weekly cyclus: up)
25: ?
26: ?
27: ?
Current 7-day averages are at 1025 a day, and I expect this to be about 5% less than the previous week with possible increases in a future weeks

Deaths lag cases by about 3 weeks.
Deaths are slowing down, as cases have slowed.
Still, cases of B.1.1.7, which is almost twice as deadly as ancestral strains, are coming up.
Cases/day slowed substantially around Feb. 19, nearly plateauing, corresponding to deaths around March 12.
Deaths since then have been in range of 1200 to 1400/day, 7-day moving average, less over the past few days as death reports are still coming in. Cases/day should continue gently declining, in parallel with cases/day 3 weeks ago.
Perhaps expect a range of 1100/day to 1400/day for the week.
1100/day * 7 = 7700
1400/day * 7 = 9800
If the question is answered on April 4, then we can expect underreporting of the past 3 days or so by about 600.
I think the lower end of my range above is much more likely.
So I think 1100 to 1200/day is most likely, or even a bit lower.
1100/day * 7 = 7700
1200/day * 7 = 8400
Subtract 600, and we get 7100 to 7800.
Numbers would have to be ~1230/day to get to 8000 cases for the week, taking into account underreporting of about 600 cases by April 4. I don't think that's very likely. And deaths could well move below 1100/day. But I don't think they'll move below a1000/day 7-day average.

Numbers have been dropping this week (444 on Monday and 650 on Tuesday) it is Wednesday, and last week the average seemed around 1000-1500. Taking an estimate of 1000 deaths per day, it is likely that deaths will be between 6000 and 8000.

Daily deaths came in at 640, a drop of 200 compared to last week.  If this holds, we would end right around 6000.  So it looks like a toss-up to me.  This is more inline with expected deaths given cases 3 weeks ago.

Recent data shows a moving average just over 7000 per week. Case data rate was level 3 weeks ago, so I expect the rate to remain stable this week.  Possibility of lower due to the fact that the death rate seems higher that I would expect based on the case rate 3 weeks ago. Perhaps this is a reporting issue that will correct this week. We may see some vaccine effect this week.
7-day-moving average as of 21 March: 1048 (*7=7336); trend: flattening

In recent weeks, the number of COVID-19 deaths has declined. Overall, deaths have decreased for the past 9 weeks. The current 7-day moving average of new deaths (1,025) decreased 69.7% compared with the highest peak on January 13, 2021 (3,379), and 10.7% compared with the peak on August 1, 2020 (1,148).  As of March 17, 2021, a total of 535,217 COVID-19 deaths were reported.
7-day-moving average as of 20 March: 1081 (*7=7567); trend: flattening
7-day-moving average as of 19 March: 1125 (*7=7875); trend: flattening
7-day-moving average as of 18 March: 1188 (*7=8316); trend: flattening

Threshold for 6k is 850 per day, for 8k its 1.1k per day and 10k its 1.4K.  
To be precise 10k is 1,428 per day.
7-day-moving average as of 17 March: 1173 (*7=8211); trend: flattening
I'll bet on the downward trend continuing, but probably not below 6,000.
7-day-moving average as of 16 March: 1228 (*7=8596); trend: flattening
Based on cross-correlation, deaths lag confirmed cases by 17 days. Linear regression with this lag predicts 7337 deaths for the week ending 27 March 2021.

Threshold for 6k is 850 per day, for 8k its 1.1k per day and 10k its 1.4K.  To be precise 10k is 1,428 per day.
Hovering just below 1.4K per day for last few days.
Cases have steadied which suggests so will deaths.  Could be close around the 10k mark.

Source: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths
- week ending 13 March= 12,087
- week ending 6 March=14,542 The number of cases and deaths is decreasing and there is no reason for them to increase again (vaccines, season) If -2,500/week during 2 weeks=>7,087
But the slope of new deaths has decreased very drastically between these 2 weeks, it is possible that it decreases less quickly
If -2,000/week=>8,087
7-day-moving average as of 15 March: 1282 (*7=8974); trend: flattening

Threshold for 6k is 850 per day, for 8k its 1.1k per day and 10k its 1.4K.
Tipping back up towards 1.5k
Cases have steadied which suggests so will deaths.  Could be close around the 10k mark.

Because deaths usually lag behind cases by about 2 weeks, we need to look at cases data from the week ending march 13. The fatality rate is about 2.16% right now so 2.16 of every 100 cases will result in deaths. The Johns Hopkins data only has number up to march 11th so I took all the cases from march 5th to march 11th and added them up to get 379489 cases for that 7 day span. I multiplied that by the 2.16% mortality rate to get 8,196 projected deaths for the week ending march 27

There has been a sustained steadier period of drop in confirmed cases, one that hasn't been reflected in the deaths. I am expecting that to occur at some point. If that doesn't happen soon, then the probabilities for the lowest two bins will be increased.

Threshold for 6k is 850 per day, for 8k its 1.1k per day and 10k its 1.4K.
Looks to be steadying out just under 1.4K
Cases have steadied which suggests so will deaths.  Could be close around the 10k mark.
A linear model based on the past 4 full weeks predicts 5777 deaths.  The number of deaths is estimated to be normally distributed around this number with a standard deviation of 1440.4 deaths.
Hard to guage, and these death number like to dance around.
Its difficult to say, because it is not sure that the injection have the result wich it should have . . !?

Threshold for 6k is 850 per day, for 8k its 1.1k per day and 10k its 1.4K.
Current rate 1.3k and dropping.
7-day-moving average as of 8 March: 1584, 3.5% down from yesterday

According to this page the reported death rate in total new was 800 + 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#cases_casesper100klast7days

The CDC forecasts that COVID deaths in 2 weeks will be approximately 9,996. 
https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklycases

28.2.-6.3 (also sunday to saturday).: 12619, 7-day-average 1800, this question is about two weeks later. 7-day-moving average as of 8 March: 1640, trend further down Scenario 1: numbers growing again: unlikely (weather and vaccines; no holidays as far as I know)
Scenario 2: current numbers: 7*1640= 11480
Scenario 3: current numbers down 10%=10332
Scenario 4: current numbers 20% down=9184  Center: around 10000

Lowering forecast for now as U.S. deaths have generally been declining over the last days and weeks. (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html)  A possible spring-season surge in cases (e.g., resulting from relaxed safety measures and/or new virus variants) may not significantly affect this statistic until after the question's time period. (https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/09/health/us-coronavirus-tuesday/index.html)
Expecting the decline in death rate to slow slightly as a consequence of the slowing rate of case numbers since 20th Feb.

New data from worldometers (which tends to report more cases than the source being used for determination of outcome) shows under 800 per day for two days (That's 5600 weekly).  If this continues, we will be below 6000.
Weekly mortality rate is declining, as are hospital admissions, whilst vaccination rates increasing.....

Recent seven-day average of deaths per day reported for the U.S. equals about 1,642/day (through 3/7/21). (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html) Keeping the forecast on the higher side for now

Amending forecast down slightly to total 8,250-10,250
Based on slowing decline of case numbers over the last three weeks, and expecting the death rate to start to reduce more slowly by approx 2,000 per week over next three weeks.

About 1,000 deaths in late February/early March 2021 per week were caused by Virginia's belated processing of death certificates of their "post-holiday case surge in January 2021" and have been inflating U.S. total deaths until lately. As this is unlikely to repeat in any state in the same manner, it is lowering the base rate for the future. It shows, however, how fragile the process is to achieve truthful and meaningful reporting that timely reflects trends, and other factors may play a role in the future for the outcome of this question. @OH

Deaths are running at a higher case fatality rate than recently. I built a random forest model over the past view months related recent cases to future death over the next few weeks. Many of those who will die during the forecast week already have the disease, so cases is a good leading indicator.  On this trend, it looks like we will be around 8000.

Current daily rate is 1700 which is a smidgen under 12k for the week.  As rates are likely to slightly drop off, but don’t expect it to drop off loads, then most likely to be in 10-12k range.  Maintaining forecast

I assume deaths lag new cases by two weeks.  The NYT site reports the level of new cases in the US stabilized about two weeks ago, so I'd expect the current death rate to continue.    The NYT site lists about 2500 deaths per day.  (I'm too busy to learn the JH's data set.)  It should be very slightly downward due to improvements in healthcare, but the level of error in the numbers should be more significant than that.  -- I see others are looking at the NYT site and seeing lower current numbers.   I don't know where they are seeing that on the NYT page, but it sounds like our approach is roughly the same.  -- Update a few minutes later:  One mistake in my prediction is using 2500/day.  I see that's just today's total, but today was high.  The average recently has been lower.  Perhaps 1500/day if I eyeball it.

For reference the average of new deaths per day in the U.S. over the last five days = 1,870, per this source: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html Keeping the forecast on the higher side until consistent improvement in these numbers is seen.

For the last seven days (02/27-03/05), the COVID death count is 12,422. Due to states opening up but also continued vaccine rollout, there is a likely chance that the number of deaths will be between 10k and 14k.

Expecting a slow decline then more pronounced over next couple of weeks, creating average daily 1,400-1,650
Current forecast 9,800-11,500 total, to be updated every few days

While vaccine roll out may increase, States like Texas that have rescinded the Mask mandate and other restrictions will offset any gains made by increasing vaccinations. 
The death rate will therefore remain fairly constant at about 2000 a day until more of the population (25% and greater) is vaccinated.
Current weekly figure about 13k.  Most likely to drop off.  Any impact of restrictions loosening now would take more than a month to serious impact deaths, so outer bounds for now at 10-14k

About 2360-2460 new U.S. deaths reported yesterday, 3/3/21. The current 7-day U.S. average ("new confirmed COVID deaths") is around 1,835 deaths per day. (https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2020/us/coronavirus-us-cases.html#anomaly-notes, https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA) These numbers will need to come down to realize some of the more optimistic predictions.
Correcting binning error. Based on case rates, vaccine impact
Based on the predicted case rate (about 425000 weekly), we should be below 6000.  With vaccines, probably less.

There were 14,000 deaths in the week prior to March 3. Texas and Mississippi are opening business and drop the mask mandate which will increase the number of deaths but vaccine efforts will start paying off.

U.S. "Daily new confirmed COVID-19 deaths", rolling 7-day average from this source through 3/2/21 is 2,046 deaths/day, with an overall decline in recent weeks. https://ourworldindata.org/covid-deaths?country=~USA Trying a more or less arbitrary 90% of the recent average (above) as one element of an initial forecast, and will adjust as we get closer to 3/21/21. (2046 X .9 =  a 7-day average of about 1,787 deaths. 1787 X 7 days = a rough guesstimate of about 12,500 deaths possible for the question's upcoming week.) Also considered: The CDC currently forecasts about 8,860 deaths for the period three weeks ahead from now: https://covid.cdc.gov/covid-data-tracker/#forecasting_weeklydeaths (Also considered:) A current news story possibly of relevance: https://www.cnn.com/2021/03/03/health/us-coronavirus-wednesday/index.html

Deaths usually lag about 3 weeks from just eyeballing the charts. That means we probably still have at least 2 weeks of a decline in deaths. Though this current bump does lower my certainty some, the fact that there was anomaly a week ago still being included in the weekly total makes me think it's likely to keep going down. After the lag catches up it's anybody's guess, and it's possible cases could continue downward as well. From February 3rd to February 17th weekly deaths dropped about 7k. I'm guessing a drop in deaths similar to that by around two weeks from now. Additionally, unlike cases vaccines are having an effect on deaths by now, as a large portion of the elderly have been vaccinated. To me that means there's more potential for deaths to drop than to rise going forward. https://ourworldindata.org/coronavirus-data-explorer?zoomToSelection=true&time=earliest..latest&country=~USA&region=World&deathsMetric=true&interval=weekly&smoothing=0&pickerMetric=location&pickerSort=asc
